title: How to know if you are straight or gay - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m going to take this as a sincere question and try to give a sincere answer. When I was five, I was caught playing “doctor” in the nude with the kid from across the street. We were in the dog house, figuratively in the dog house once caught, literally in it when caught. We took off our clothes and crawled into a dog house. In our favor, it was a big dog house. We instinctively knew there was something wrong with what we were doing, but were intent on doing it nonetheless. We had been fervently examining each other’s every part for perhaps half an hour when my grandmother reached in and dragged me out. She knew we were in there because we had neatly and conscientiously folded our clothes and placed them just outside the structure. Not in our favor. I remember this not because we were having sex or behaving sexually toward each other. I was five; he was six. We had no idea what sex was. Sexuality was a concept entirely beyond our ken. What I remember was the aching need in my gut for a ‘special’ friend, a male friend, and we would have great intimacy. Other than that description, I didn’t really know what I needed. I didn’t know how to express it. I wouldn’t figure it out until I was thirteen. I went through puberty at eleven, fifth grade. My mother sat me down with an anatomy reference book and explained ‘the facts’ to me: hormones, pubic hair, penile growth, erections, sex, sexuality. I didn’t really understand sexuality, but I understood sexual attraction — to another guy. It arose in me daily. And, that aching need was there with a vengeance. I began to associate the two with each other. I still hadn’t a name or external reference for it. I thought I was the only one. By thirteen, seventh grade, I had a name and a reference. The name was homosexual. The reference was from Leviticus. It was abomination, perversion, and evil. I knew I was one. I had no doubt. I hadn’t the slightest interest in girls, not just sexually but also emotionally and intellectually. I was sexually attracted to guys. I had the erections and day-dreaming fantasies to prove it. I routinely jerked off to the men’s underwear ads in the Sears & Roebuck catalog. I discovered the version of gay porn at the time, men’s athletic posing magazines. And there was that familiar aching need. Only now, it wasn’t content just to occupy my gut. It moved to a point behind my sternum and took up residence. It left a yawning gap where blood and tissue should have been. It smarted and gnawed at my serenity. Now you too have an internal reference for homosexuality. You have me as an example. For an external reference, Wikiwand has an article on homosexuality. Homosexuality is romantic attraction, sexual attraction or sexual behavior between members of the same sex or gender. As a sexual orientation, homosexuality is "an enduring pattern of emotional, romantic, and/or sexual attractions" to people of the same sex. If you have experienced not just occasional homosexual conduct, but instead a continuing emotional investment, you’re gay. You may have had no homosexual contact but nonetheless, have that gnawing ache that won’t go away. That is an enduring pattern of emotional/romantic same-sex attraction. That is same-sex sexual orientation. That is gay. If instead you have none of that but have had a couple of homosexual encounters without the ache feasting behind your sternum, your straight and just experimenting. If you’ve had several homosexual and heterosexual encounters, and if you’ve enjoyed them both and want to continue with them, you’re bisexual. It doesn’t much matter whether you’re sexually inexperienced. It doesn’t much matter whether you’re five, thirteen, twenty, or thirty-five. What matters is whether you have that enduring pattern of same-sex emotional/romantic attraction, the ache that won’t be satisfied unless you find a man to empathize with and intimately relate to. If yes, you’re gay. If not, not at all, you’re straight. If something else, you’re bisexual. If you’re worrying about it, stop. Just let things play out as they will. Explore, experiment, and don’t worry about putting a name to it. With time and with the knowledge that comes from experience, you will know for sure whether you’re gay.  Q: How do you know for sure if you are gay?

Yes. I am a good example - I’m as gay as they come, but I am what the queer community often calls “straight acting” - my most comfortable modes of appearance and behaviors are pretty heteronormative. I am a big guy, I grow my beard out, I’m physically strong, I dress masculine, etc. etc.. This doesn’t make any statements about my being better or worse, of course, than a more effeminate gay man! It’s just who I am. Being gay and being effeminate are two different things that, ultimately, have little to do with one another other than subcultural norms. Check out this infographic for a little helpful context:  What a person’s outward appearance and behaviors that you’re asking about when you say “straight-looking” are what we call “Gender Expression”: how a person chooses to and is comfortable dressing and acting with regards to traditionally masculine and feminine modes. This can be any degree along either concept, or a combination of the two, OR vary from day to day or moment to moment. While these might signal different things socially as a form of non-verbal communication, they are not actually tied to sexual or romantic orientation (attraction). So, a biological male might have a feminine gender, be sexually attracted to males but romantically attracted to neither gender (aka, wants sex, but not a relationship), and oscillate between masculine dress and behaviors and feminine ones from day to day. Or any other combination thereof. Wibbly-wobbly humany-wumany: There’s lots of ways of being human.

Sometimes it takes a while. When I was eighteen, I went to university. This was the first time I’d been away from home and in an environment where other young people were actively interested in sex. In my first year, I was in a hall of residence - and I never found the right girl. (Found out several years later that at least one had been dropping pretty big hints, and I had been utterly oblivious…) I did, however, get rather distracted by surfer dude Brian and by Paul, who was quite happy after his shower to hang around the kitchen in just a towel. Second year, I moved off campus. I was very lonely. The urge to find a girlfriend grew stronger but I still couldn’t find “the one”. And then that summer, aged twenty, I did something I’d never done before. I got some prescription sunglasses. No more squinting in the sunlight. One of the hidden bonuses of sunglasses is that you can check out everyone that walks by without worrying that they’ll notice. I was young, horny and desperate, so I took advantage of this. And I suddenly realised that I wasn’t looking at the girls. I was drawn to the guys, showing off those muscular legs in their short shorts and often going entirely topless. Oh dear. My life had turned complicated. But not so much. I joined the university LGBT group, largely on the grounds that they could maybe tell me for sure. They introduced me to various bars, a gay youth group… and eventually I came to terms with it all. Still took me a while to find a boyfriend, but that was largely due to social clumsiness. How do you know? Put on some sunglasses, walk down the street, and watch what your eyes are doing.

Let's say you're a man. Imagine yourself making out with a hot girl. Imagine getting down on one knee, asking this woman to marry you. Imagine yourself at the hospital, holding your first child for the first time. Imagine sitting next to this woman on the porch, both near the end of your life, contemplating your marriage. Can you see yourself doing this? Yes? You probably like women. You may be straight. You may not be. Can you not see yourself doing this? You probably don't like women. You may not be straight. Now, imagine you're making out with a hot guy. Imagine getting on one knee, asking him to marry you. Imagine going through the struggles to get a marriage certificate, to make your love for one another valid. Imagine trying to adopt a child, because you know that together, you'll parent the shit out of your kids. Imagine sitting next to your husband, with the same love you have the day you met him. Can you see yourself doing this, and the same with a woman? You're probably bisexual. Or maybe you aren't. Can you see yourself only doing this? You probably like men. You might be gay. You might not be. Finding out you're gay or straight isn't a test you can take. It isn't something anyone else can figure out for you. It is a realization you need to make yourself. (Notice that I said realization and not choice because sexuality is not a choice.)

Yes. Appearance has no impact on sexuality whatsoever. Earlier this year I went to my first pride parade, together with a straight friend of mine.Take a look at my profile picture. I’m a short guy with long hair, a goatee, wear black clothing, and generally dress in a way that makes people immediately place me as ‘metalhead’ (which is indeed true). Now that day, I went to some lengths to make sure I looked attractive, putting on a shirt that shows off what I pretend is an attractive, muscular body, paying extra attention to my shave and hair, etc. My friend habitually has a very clean shave, spends significant amounts of time styling his hair for those occasions, and generally likes to dress to look good. During the parade he was flirted with by several guys, and constantly had to decline with the words “Sorry, I’m straight. He’s bisexual though.” (referring to me). It was generally met with variations of “What, really?”. People kept pinning him as the gay one, and me as the straight friend who came along, when it was actually the other way round. He is apparently often thought of as gay; both another friend of his and his current girlfriend at first thought he was gay. People don’t “look gay” or “look straight”. The only reliable method of finding out someone’s sexuality is by asking them politely.

Is it possible for a fully straight-looking person to be gay? Define “straight looking”. In my experience, gay people don't grow extra limbs, or glow funny colours. I know a bloke who's over six and a half feet tall, covered in tattoos, keen on skulls, mohawk, built like a brick privy, winner of a prize for belicose, drunken vomiting at a Pagan camp. I was stunned when he came out, but glad that he felt able to express himself, even though he lost some “friends” as a result. I also know a teacher, speaking as a heterosexual man, she was a joy to behold, still is, she came out and I felt an idiotic pang of disappointment, as if a woman like that would be interested in a face-ache like me! In both cases, there were no outward signs of their sexual orientation. Conversely, I've been told that I'm gay, had people demand that I admit it, because I hate sport and, until recently, had long hair. I find other men physically repulsive, especially in a sexual way, so it's hardly surprising that my response was initially hilarity, graduating to anger and leaving the conversation before I resorted to violence, which apparently proved the idiot’s point. You can't tell a person's sexuality from their appearance.

Those aren’t the only options and that can make answering this question for yourself pretty difficult. Most people think of sexuality as a spectrum ranging (at least) from gay to straight. So, you can be mostly straight and a little gay. Or one could be perfectly bisexual where you’re equally “gay” and “straight.” I knew I was gay because I am a man who is primarily interested in other men for sex and romance. This doesn’t mean I never find women attractive nor that I’ve never considered having sex with women. But, really, I am mostly and most consistently attracted to men. So, I’m gay. If I’m being perfectly frank with you, though, I don’t think it’s absolutely necessary to answer this question for one’s self. It’s handy and convenient to have a label that tells you what’s expected of you, but if you find yourself in a situation where your emotions contradict that label, it can create some difficulties. For example, if you’re convinced you’re gay, but then you meet someone of the other gender who pushes your buttons, you’re forced to ask yourself what that means for your personal identity. I think that’s actually one of the reasons why it can be difficult to come out of the closet. If I were to imagine an ideal society for people, I wouldn’t make this an issue at all. People would just accept the fact that they’re attracted to other people without feeling a need to build their whole identity around that attraction. They could be with men or women based on who they and their partners are. But we don’t live in an imaginary world and I know that people want to be able to figure out which boxes they fit in.

Ok, let me make something very clear. That flamboyant guy who is so tooootally gay you see on the TV all the time, or the butch lesbian you see fixing cars and watching football whilst drinking a cold one with the boys. Yeah, those are stereotypes. Sexuality in itself has absolutely no effect on such behavior whatsoever. Of course, most people assume these stereotypes as the majority, as these are usually very extroverted personalities, thus, they are the most visible, and when it’s associated with homosexuality, that tends to be the only part of the community that’s seen. So there is some truth to the stereotype, but that’s far from all gay people, if even most, if even a significant percentage. A good amount of gay people, you probably wouldn’t be able to deduct their sexuality as easily as the stereotyped personality - in other words, a good amount of gay people, if not most gay people, act mostly like straight people, you just don’t know it, because they’re not making a huge show if effeminacy or masculinity that isn’t typical for their gender identity. ( Which isn’t to say there’s anything wrong with acting that way, the problem simply lies in the fact that it’s a stereotype, and not a very healthy one for people outside of the LGBTQ+ community to be grouping all gay people in ) I myself am gay, and I’ve been told that I’m mostly straight-passing. While I’m certainly not the most masculine macho-man on the face of the Earth, and do have a few minor feminine-oriented tendencies, I don’t really outwardly do much that adheres to the stereotypes of my sexuality, nor is the fact that I’m gay terribly obvious to most people in general. Most of my other gay friends are the same way, though some others are closer to the stereotype. Regardless, the point is just like straight people, gay people are diverse in personality, their sexuality has no direct effect on that, period.

The general consensus is if you are attracted to men exclusively and are a man, then you are gay. If you are a man who is attracted exclusively to women, you are straight. Plot twist: if you are attracted to either men or women within the binary (and this includes trans people because trans men are men and trans women are women), you are bisexual. If you are attracted to a person regardless of gender including intersex, etc. (i.e., you don’t give a shit what gender they identify as), then you’re pansexual. The reality is that pansexual and bisexual often intersect and overlap. The individual is allowed to define it as they see fit. Epilogue: Only you can answer this question for yourself. No one has the right to dictate your sexuality to you.

Thanks for the A2A. It's really simple, but first I should point out how those aren't the only two sexual orientations. It's not one or the other. But since you narrowed it down to those two, we’ll deal with them. You're going to need two decent people, one of the same sex and one of the opposite. Date each of them for three months. Take note of how you feel about them sexually, emotionally, and physically. Especially make sure to focus more on how their gender affects your attraction. Break up with them after the time period. Think of who you really felt into. Think if you were extremely reluctant or even repulsed from doing with them. There are a lot of factors that impact your attraction. Their personality might skewer the results, however you might notice that you prefer one personality over the other. If you don't want to do that, then you take the very simple way: going through life. Usually in your 20’s you have a good idea of who you're into. Sexual orientation isn't something you should test. It's very fluid and you can be a variety of things you thought you never were.

Put it in context - remember it’s a sexual preference, then ask another question: Do you think that you can often tell if someone prefers brunettes?Do you think that you can often tell if someone is into thighs or breasts? Unless they are being very obvious about it, none of these are easily answered with quick interactions. The amount of time required would correlate very well with the amount of effort a person is putting into not putting out signals. For example, it would be easier to determine if someone is indeed into you sexually at a bar than at a board meeting; the signals are more obvious (and acceptable) in one location over the other. Similarly, some folk are better at picking up signals, or are just simply more observant - a guy might not realise he’s being blatantly scoped out by another guy because that simply doesn’t enter his mind-space that another guy would do that, whereas a woman might be used to constantly getting attention, even the most subtle of cues, from men, that when she doesn’t, it’s completely obvious to her. And vice versa, too.

If you answered yes twice, you are bisexual If you answered no, you are asexual or aromantic  This is overly simplified, as there are other genders, and bisexual is attraction to the same as you and others (your gender and all other genders), but you asked specifically about straight or gay. As others have said, appearance has NO impact on a person’s sexuality whatsoever. Everyone, and I mean everyone, thinks I’m straight. When they learn otherwise, they’re all pretty surprised. So apparently, I don’t “look gay”. I play softball, which is stereotypically a lesbian sport. Last year, my best friend said “I bet you’re the only straight one on your team.” I had only come out to one other person at that point, and I took my chance and ran with it. “Well, actually…” - and that’s how I came out to my best friend. Appearance doesn’t matter. A person can dress feminine, masculine, androgynous, colorful, monochromatic, bright, dull, patterned or plain, have long hair or short, wear makeup or not… it doesn’t matter. Their orientation(s) are unaffected by their choice of appearance (though sometimes the opposite can be true - orientation can affect choice of appearance). Basically, anyone can be gay, straight, bi, pan, poly, ace, aro. Looks have nothing to do with it.

Straight: When you’re straight, you are sexually attracted to members of genders other than your own, but not for those of the same gender as you. Gay: When you’re gay, you’re only sexually attracted to members of the same sex and you don't have sexual or romantic feelings for the opposite sex. Only you can determine who you feel sexual attraction to. Think about: Do you imagine yourself kissing a boy or kissing a girl? What feels more comfortable to you? Who do you find more attractive?
